Because they take as their essence and characteristics the non-discriminating Å›amatha, vipaÅ›yanÄ, etc.

Moreover, their characteristics are the knowledge of the equality of the equalized object and subject, because by this [knowledge] one realizes the true suchness that is devoid of the nature of the grasped and grasper.

Moreover, the characteristics of the knowledge of the object that is the universal negation of the two provisional realities, the provisional reality of individual sentient beings and the provisional reality of individual dharmas, are taken as its characteristics.
How are the characteristics of the knowledge of the object that is the negation of the provisional reality of individual sentient beings taken as its characteristics?
Because by this knowledge, within one's own mental continuum, one does not discriminate the characteristics of self.
Not discriminating means the meaning of eliminating.
How are the characteristics of the knowledge of the object that is the negation of the provisional reality of individual dharmas taken as its characteristics?
Because this cognition does not discriminate the characteristics of form and other dharmas in one's own mental continuum.
How is the cognition of dharmas characterized by the object of universal negation?
Because this cognition is undifferentiated in all places and does not discriminate the characteristics of self and dharmas.

Furthermore, if the differences in the path of seeing are explained separately, it is as follows: immediately after the supreme worldly dharmas, there is the receptivity to the cognition of the dharma of suffering, the cognition of the dharma of suffering, the receptivity to the cognition of the subsequent knowledge of suffering, the cognition of the subsequent knowledge of suffering, the receptivity to the cognition of the dharma of the origin [of suffering], the cognition of the dharma of the origin [of suffering], the receptivity to the cognition of the subsequent knowledge of the origin [of suffering], the cognition of the subsequent knowledge of the origin [of suffering], the receptivity to the cognition of the dharma of the cessation [of suffering], the cognition of the dharma of the cessation [of suffering], the receptivity to the cognition of the subsequent knowledge of the cessation [of suffering], the cognition of the subsequent knowledge of the cessation [of suffering], the receptivity to the cognition of the dharma of the path [to the cessation of suffering], the cognition of the dharma of the path [to the cessation of suffering], the receptivity to the cognition of the subsequent knowledge of the path [to the cessation of suffering], and the cognition of the subsequent knowledge of the path [to the cessation of suffering]. There are thus sixteen kinds.

Among the noble truths, the receptivity to the cognition of the dharma and the cognition of the dharma, as well as the receptivity to the cognition of the subsequent knowledge and the cognition of the subsequent knowledge, are the characteristics of the differences in the path of seeing.
Suffering refers to the truth of suffering.
The dharma of suffering refers to the teachings that are arisen due to the predominance of the truth of suffering.
Dharma knowledge refers to the knowledge of the superior dharmas that observes the truths in the path of preparation.

Knowledge acceptance refers to the uncontaminated wisdom that directly realizes the individual truth of suffering through the power of prior observation and superiority. By this wisdom, one permanently abandons all the afflictions to be eliminated by seeing the truth of suffering.

The meaning explained here refers to the wisdom that observes the dharmas such as the sutras that arise based on the truth of suffering in the path of preparation. Through the power of superiority of wisdom that is included in proper attention, one directly realizes the suchness of the truth of suffering in one's own continuum. The essence of supramundane wisdom and right view arises. By this wisdom, one permanently abandons all the twenty-eight latent afflictions bound to the three realms to be eliminated by seeing the truth of suffering. Therefore, it is called the acceptance of the knowledge of the dharmas of suffering.
The knowledge of the dharmas of suffering refers to the knowledge by which, immediately after acceptance, one attains liberation from the previously eliminated afflictions and realizes them.
Why is it so?

First, through patience one eternally eliminates all the passions that are eliminated by insight into suffering. The support is transformed. Immediately after this, through such knowledge, one realizes the transmutation of the support. This is called knowledge of the factors of the path of insight into suffering.

The patience that is knowledge of the similarity of suffering is the pure discernment that arises immediately after the patience that is knowledge of the factors of the path of insight into suffering and that is directed toward that patience and that knowledge.
Each one realizes internally that all subsequent holy dharmas are of the same species as this.
Why is this?
Because the first two kinds of patience and knowledge are the species of all subsequent holy dharmas of training and beyond training, because they are born from them.
Therefore, pure discernment arises and each one realizes internally that subsequent holy dharmas are of the same species as this.
Therefore it is called the patience that is knowledge of the similarity of suffering.

Knowledge of the similarity of suffering is the pure knowledge that arises immediately after this patience and that examines and confirms the patience that is knowledge of the similarity of suffering.
Why is this?

Because immediately after the receptivity to the knowledge of the class of suffering, a pure knowledge is born that internally realizes and approves of the receptivity to the knowledge of the class of suffering, it is called the knowledge of the class of suffering.

In this way, in the other truths, according to what is appropriate, all receptivities and all knowledges should be understood. In this stage, by the receptivities to the knowledge of dharmas and the knowledge of dharmas, one awakens to the grasped; by the receptivities to the knowledge of the classes and the knowledge of the classes, one awakens to the grasper.
Why is this?

The supramundane path has two objects, namely suchness and right knowledge. The path of the class of knowledge of dharmas takes suchness as its object, and the path of the class of knowledge of classes takes right knowledge as its object. Because of this, all receptivities and knowledges truly understand.

Moreover, in this stage of all receptivities and knowledges, it is said that one abides in signless contemplation. As the Blessed One said, The person who abides in the sixth signless abode is precisely the one who presently abides in this stage of receptivities and knowledges, because in this stage all signs are unobtainable.
Moreover, the stage of signlessness has six kinds, namely emptiness, signlessness, wishlessness, concentration of cessation, the peak of existence, and the path of seeing.
These sixteen moments of mind are called the path of seeing.
Why is this?

Because these sixteen moments of mind consisting of acceptance and knowledge, which are included in the four moments each, see the four noble truths that have never been seen before, it is called the path of seeing.
Moreover, a moment of mind refers to the final realization of the arising of knowledge regarding the known object, not just the arising of what was previously nonexistent.
Why is this?
Because up to the arising of the knowledge that can know the known object, the final realization is called a moment of mind.
It is said that the thorough understanding of suffering is one moment of mind. The same is so for the complete abandonment of the origin and so forth.
Moreover, as explained above, the distinctions of the path of seeing are all conventionally established, not truly so.
Why is this?
Because in the stage of transcendence of the world, each one realizes internally and cuts off idle discourse.
Next, all truths of the path are to be understood through four aspects: establishment, reflection, realization, and perfection.

Establishment refers to the Å›rÄvakas and others, who, having attained their own realization and reached the ultimate, wish to cause others to understand as well. By means of subsequently attained cognition, they establish the truth of the path using immeasurable kinds of names, phrases, and sentences, saying, In regard to the truths, there is such and such patience, such and such knowledge, and so forth.
Reflection refers to the correct cultivation of the expedient means of realization, using mundane cognition to reflect and cultivate repeatedly as established.

Realization refers to having cultivated in this way, one internally realizes and experiences for the first time the path of seeing, correctly transcending the world and entering the stage of no idle discourse.
Perfection refers to after this stage, perfecting the transformation of the basis until attaining the ultimate.
Having already realized the ultimate stage, they again use subsequently attained cognition to establish the truth of the path by means of the aggregates of name, phrase, and syllable.
In this way, the four aspects of the true path wheel revolve in succession, supporting each other and turning without interruption.
As a scripture says, When the dust and dirt are removed, the Dharma eye is born with regard to dharmas. This is said on the basis of the path of insight.
The forbearances with regard to dharmas remove the dust, and the knowledges with regard to dharmas remove the dirt, because they are by nature the noble wisdom eye with regard to the truths.
The forbearances with regard to dharmas remove the dust, because the forbearances with regard to dharmas eternally eliminate all dust of the passions.
The knowledges with regard to dharmas remove the dirt, because the knowledges with regard to dharmas are born in dependence on the removal of the dirt of the obstacles.

Also, in these two states of forbearance and knowledge, the path is purified by means of complete knowledge and eternal elimination, and on the basis of this, it is said that the dust is removed and the dirt is eliminated.

What is the path of cultivation?

It refers to the worldly path, supramundane path, soft path, middling path, superior path, path of skillful means, uninterrupted path, path of liberation, path of progress, etc., that exist above the path of seeing. All of these are called the path of cultivation.
Why is it so?

The holy disciples of the buddhas who have already attained the insight of the truths, from this point on, in order to eliminate the remaining bonds, frequently practice the worldly path, etc., as a skillful means. This is called the path of cultivation.

The worldly path refers to the worldly first concentration, second concentration, third concentration, and fourth concentration, the sphere of infinite space, the sphere of infinite consciousness, the sphere of nothingness, and the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
These concentrations and formless attainments should be extensively distinguished by means of four aspects: defiled, pure, established, and purified.
As for the defiled, there are four indeterminate roots:
first, craving; second, views; third, pride; fourth, ignorance.

Because these four delusions defile the mind, they cause all the defiled concentrations and formless attainments to give rise to the afflictions and secondary afflictions of the form and formless realms without interruption.
Why is it so?
Because of craving, one is defiled by the defilement of craving for the higher meditative absorptions, because one craves the bliss of the comfort of pure meditative absorption.

Because of views, one is defiled by the defilement of views regarding the higher meditative absorptions, because one gives rise to views such as that of the beginning of things, etc., on the basis of meditative absorption.

Because of pride, one is defiled by the defilement of pride regarding the higher meditative absorptions, because one gives rise to a sense of superiority on the basis of the attainment of superior meditative absorption.

Because of ignorance, one is defiled by the defilement of doubt regarding the higher meditative absorptions, because one who seeks liberation, because of not yet penetrating the truth, always gives rise to doubt regarding the superior realization, wondering whether it is liberation or not.
In this way, these passions always defile the mind and cause the two kinds of passions of form and formlessness to continue in a series and evolve.
The pure refers to pure meditative absorption and formlessness, which are called pure because they are by nature good.
Even though they are mundane, they are also called pure because they are free of the bonds and stains.

As for establishment, there are four kinds of establishment, namely, establishment of factors, establishment of meditative attainments, establishment of categories, and establishment of names and concepts.
In the various meditations, there is establishment of all four;
in the formless [absorptions], there are only three kinds, excluding establishment of factors.
As for establishment of factors, it refers to the first meditation having five factors.
What are the five?
First, initial thought; second, sustained thought; third, joy; fourth, pleasure; fifth, one-pointedness of mind.
The second meditation has four factors.
What are the four?
First, inner serenity; second, joy; third, pleasure; fourth, one-pointedness of mind.
The third meditation has five factors.
What are the five?
First, equanimity; second, mindfulness; third, right knowledge; fourth, pleasure; fifth, one-pointedness of mind.
The fourth meditation has four factors.
What are the four?
First, pure abandonment, second, pure mindfulness, third, neither painful nor pleasant feeling, fourth, one-pointedness of mind.
Question:
Why are only investigation, etc. established as factors among the innumerable dharmas?
Answer:
Because they are the factors of counteraction, the factors of benefit, and the factors of intrinsic nature that are the basis of those two.
Because these three kinds of factors are complete and do not depend on others.
In the first dhyÄna, investigation and analysis are the factors of counteraction, because they can eliminate the investigation, anger, and harm, etc. of the desire realm.
Joy and pleasure are the factors of benefit. Because the factors of investigation and analysis have eliminated what is to be eliminated, one attains the joy and pleasure of separation.
One-pointedness of mind is the factor of intrinsic nature that is the basis of those two. Because investigation, etc. arise in dependence on the power of concentration.
In the second dhyÄna, inner serenity is the factor of counteraction, because this can eliminate investigation and analysis.
Joy and pleasure are the factors of benefit.
The nature of concentration is the support for the first two, and its meaning is as explained above.
In the third trance state, equanimity, mindfulness, and right knowledge are the factors of antidotes, because these three can cure joy.
Bliss is the factor of benefit.
The nature of concentration is the support for the first two, and its meaning is as explained above.
In the fourth trance state, the purity of equanimity and the purity of mindfulness are the factors of antidotes, because these two can cure bliss.
The feeling that is neither suffering nor bliss is the factor of benefit.
The nature of concentration is the support for the first two.
In the formless [absorptions], the factors are not established, because their nature is of a single flavor of samÄdhi.
How are the meditative attainments established?
It is said that one enters the first trance state up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception through seven kinds of attention.
What are called the seven kinds of attention?

That is, the attention of discernment of characteristics, the attention of superior understanding, the attention of separation, the attention of delight in taking, the attention of investigation, the attention of the culmination of the means, and the attention of the fruit of the culmination of the means.
This is extensively distinguished in the later yoga section of the ÅšrÄvaka Stage.
How does one enter the first trance state by means of the seven kinds of attention?
That is, by means of the attention of the stage of concentration, one sees the faults, etc., in the realm of desire and therefore discerns the characteristics of coarseness.
Because these characteristics do not exist in the first trance state, it is called the characteristic of tranquility.
This is called the attention of discernment of characteristics.

This kind of attention is still mixed with hearing and thought. From this point on, one transcends hearing and thought and is exclusively in the aspect of cultivation. Taking the characteristics of coarseness and tranquility as its object, one cultivates Å›amatha and vipaÅ›yanÄ. One frequently contemplates the nature and characteristics of coarseness and tranquility as they have been investigated. This is called the attention of superior understanding.

Because of the cultivation of this, the first path of elimination is produced. The attention that accompanies it is called the attention of elimination, because it can eliminate the upper stage of the passions and because it can eliminate the grossness of that stage.ğŸ”½This contemplator is also delighted with the upper stage of elimination and the merits of seeing the upper stage of elimination. Having already touched a small part of the bliss of separation, in order to remove torpor and sleepiness, he from time to time cultivates pure and wonderful attention in order to delight his mind. This is called the attention of delight.

In this way, the practitioner, aided by the good factors of skillful means, causes the bonds and defilements associated with the realm of desire to no longer appear. Because of this, in order to examine whether the passions have been eliminated or not, he again pays attention and observes the arising of pure characteristics. This is called the attention of investigation.

Thus the practitioner repeatedly contemplates and cultivates the antidotes in order to cause all the passions of the realm of desire to be temporarily eliminated, and the attention associated with this path of antidotes is the final expedient for the first trance state and is therefore called attention of final expedient means.
Immediately after this, one realizes the attention associated with the first fundamental trance state, and this is called attention of the fruit of final expedient means.

Also, attention characterized by discernment gives rise to a mind of aspiration in order to understand thoroughly what is to be eliminated and what is to be attained, in order to eliminate and attain. Attention characterized by resolve gives rise to correct effort for the sake of the meaning sought. Attention characterized by freedom from passion eliminates the coarse passions. Attention characterized by delight eliminates the medium passions. Attention characterized by contemplation causes the mind to rest in what has been realized and eliminates the conceit of superiority. Attention characterized by final expedient means eliminates the weak passions. Attention characterized by the fruit of final expedient means is the fruit of the cultivation of the attention that has been cultivated.

For example, in order to enter the first meditative absorption, one cultivates seven types of attention. In the same way, one should understand accordingly up to in order to enter the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
Moreover, the coarse characteristics refer to all lower stages, from the desire realm up to the base of nothingness. These coarse characteristics are roughly of two kinds:
First, abiding in heavy suffering, not abiding in tranquility;
Second, the life-force is slight, and the lifespan is short.

The tranquil characteristics refer to all higher stages, from the first meditative absorption up to the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, because they are contrary to the coarse characteristics.
As for the establishment of categories, in the first meditative absorption, there are three levels of cultivation, namely soft, medium, and superior.
Just as in the first meditative absorption, the other meditative absorptions and formless [absorptions] also have three levels of cultivation.
Due to the soft, medium, and superior cultivation of the first meditative absorption, three types of karmic maturation are produced within the first meditative absorption.
The same is true for the other dhyÄnas. If one cultivates and produces results in the other dhyÄnas, there are also three grades.

As for the three grades of cultivation and production of three results in the various dhyÄnas, it refers to the BrahmakÄyika gods, Brahmapurohita gods, MahÄbrahmÄ gods, and so on, as explained in detail above.
In the formless realm, there are no separate locations, so the results of birth are not established.
Why is this?
Because in the formless realm there are no fixed palaces and other locations, the distinctions in the results of birth are not established.
However, due to the three grades of cultivation of the formless concentrations, when their karmic results are born, there are high and low, inferior and superior.
When their karmic results are born, there are high and low, because there are differences in lifespan and so on.
There are inferior and superior, because there are differences in defiled and undefiled, and many and few.
As for the establishment of names and concepts, it refers to the immeasurable names and incalculable, inconceivable distinctions of samÄdhis subsumed within the four dhyÄnas.
Why is this?

Within the samÄdhis subsumed within the first dhyÄna, the buddhas and bodhisattvas who have attained great authority enter samÄdhis, and those samÄdhis are not even understood by the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, let alone that they should be able to know their number, much less realize and enter them.
As the PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra says, there are more than a hundred samÄdhis.
Thus, in other MahÄyÄna sÅ«tras, it is said that the number of samÄdhis is immeasurable.
Just as with the samÄdhis subsumed within the first dhyÄna, it is the same with the samÄdhis subsumed within the other dhyÄnas and formless [absorptions].
What is explained here is all based on the perfection of dhyÄna.
Pure means the concentration at the limit of the first dhyana, up to the concentration at the limit of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. This is called pure dhyana.
The concentration at the limit of the formless [realms] is in order to attain mastery in the cultivation of the highest qualities and to reach the ultimate stage of the adaptable concentration.
The supramundane path refers to the knowledge of suffering, origination, cessation, and path included in the categories of dharma knowledge and inferential knowledge in the path of cultivation.
These eight knowledges have already been extensively explained in the path of seeing.
And the samadhis and so forth associated with them are either included in the preliminary concentration or included in the first dhyana up to the sphere of nothingness.
The sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is only mundane, because the perception of indistinctness always manifests.

Because the perception of indistinctness always manifests, it is not the basis for the supramundane path that operates with extreme clarity. Therefore, it is entirely included in the mundane [realms].
For this reason, their conceptualization is weak and cannot grasp the characteristics of objects with sharp clarity, so it is called signless.
How do we know that the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception has no noble path?
Because the World-Honored One said:
Up to the concentration of perception, one can truly illuminate and penetrate.
The concentration of cessation is supramundane, because it is realized after the noble path. It can only be initiated in the human realm.
As for initiate, it means to first give rise to.
Either in the human realm or in the form realm, it can be manifested, because it has already arisen and is manifested again later.
As for either in the human realm, it means in this very life.
As for in the form realm, it means being reborn there later.
How can noble disciples who have attained the formless concentrations and are free from desire for the form realm be reborn in the form realm?
One does not necessarily permanently leave the desire realm for form in order to enter the formless concentrations. Therefore, four alternatives should be made here.
If one has already left the desire realm for form, can they all enter the tranquil liberation concentration of the formless realm?
If one can enter the tranquil liberation concentration of the formless realm, have they all already left the desire realm for form?
Answer:

The first alternative refers to those who, relying on the concentration of the stage of preliminary concentration, have already left the desire realm for form, but are unable to enter the tranquil liberation concentration of the formless realm.

The second alternative refers to those noble ones who have already attained the fourth meditation, do not seek rebirth in the formless realm, but give rise to disgust and aversion, and the practice of the fourth meditation is always present before them.
Abandoning the path of severing bonds, relying on the path of progress, they are gradually able to enter the tranquil liberation concentration of the formless realm.

The third alternative refers to those practitioners who diligently seek to leave desire, relying on the path of severing bonds, and are gradually able to enter the tranquil liberation concentration of the formless realm.
The fourth line excludes the above characteristics.
Question:
Why does the concentration of cessation not arise in the formless realm?
Answer:

This concentration of cessation mostly does not arise in the formless realm, because those who abide in the tranquil liberation of retribution do not often arouse diligent effort for this concentration of cessation.
Why is this so?
Holy disciples, in order to abide in tranquil abiding, lead this concentration of cessation to manifest in the human realm and so forth.

If one has already been born in the formless realm, one naturally abides in the most tranquil liberation of retribution without effort, and does not again arouse diligent effort to seek to manifest this concentration of cessation.
The weak path refers to the weak-weak, weak-middle, and weak-upper stages of the path.
By means of this path, one is able to abandon the upper-upper, upper-middle, and upper-lower three stages of afflictions in each of the realms.
The middle path refers to the middle-weak, middle-middle, and middle-strong paths.
By means of this path, one is able to abandon the three grades of afflictions in each stage of the three realms, namely the middle-strong, middle-middle, and middle-weak.
The upper path refers to the upper-weak, upper-middle, and upper-strong three grades of paths.
By means of this path, one is able to abandon the three grades of afflictions in each stage of the three realms, namely the weak-strong, weak-middle, and weak-weak.

In this way, the weak, middle, and strong grades of paths are each further divided into three grades of weak, etc., establishing nine grades, in order to show the gradual abandonment of the afflictions eliminated by the path of cultivation.
For what reason is the weak-weak grade of path able to eliminate the strong-strong grade of afflictions?

Because these afflictions manifest as coarse and heavy in the body of one who has utterly destroyed shame and conscience, being easy to perceive and easy to discriminate. Therefore, these strong grades of afflictions, like coarse defilements, can be removed by a slight antidote.

If the lower-lower level of afflictions is present in a person, it is subtle and hidden in their body, difficult to perceive and difficult to distinguish, like a subtle and hidden stain that can only be removed by a powerful remedy.
Based on this principle, it should be understood that the remaining antidotes and objects to be eliminated are also established in the same way through mutual contrast.
The path of preparation refers to the path by which one can abandon afflictions.
Why is this?

Because when one cultivates this path in the correct way, one can gradually abandon a portion of the coarseness produced by each individual level of afflictions, and gradually attain the transformation of the basis. This is called the path of preparation within the path of cultivation.
The uninterrupted path refers to the path by which one permanently eliminates afflictions without remainder.
Why is this?
Because this path can permanently remove without remainder the coarseness produced by the afflictions of this level, leaving none remaining.
Furthermore, by transforming the basis of coarseness and obtaining non-coarseness, this is called the uninterrupted path in the path of cultivation.
The path of liberation refers to the liberation obtained by this path through the elimination of afflictions.
Why is this so?
Because by this path, one can realize the transformation of the basis obtained through the complete elimination of afflictions.
The path of progress refers to the uninterrupted and liberated paths that are the skillful means for eliminating the remaining categories of afflictions. This is called the path of progress.
Why is this so?

The uninterrupted and liberated paths that are the skillful means for eliminating the remaining afflictions after this category are the path of progress in relation to this category, and are therefore called the path of progress.

Furthermore, abandoning the skillful means for eliminating afflictions, either diligently contemplating various dharmas, or diligently abiding in various dharmas, or cultivating other samÄdhis and all the paths, is called the path of progress.
Furthermore is used to indicate other meanings.

The path of abandoning afflictions and severing bonds is the path of immediate succession. The path of correct contemplation of the teachings such as the sutras, or abiding in and observing the teachings contemplated and realized before, or entering into other superior states of concentration, all such paths are called the path of added effort.
Moreover, all paths for the sake of manifesting superior qualities or abiding in them are called the path of added effort.
Why is this?

If for the sake of manifesting superior qualities such as the supernormal powers and immeasurables, or for the sake of abiding in them after they have arisen, such paths are called the path of added effort.

Thus the characteristics and distinctions of the path of cultivation have been extensively explained. Now, continuing the discussion, we shall further distinguish the differences in the cultivation of the various paths.
What is cultivation?
In brief, there are four kinds: cultivation of attainment, cultivation of practice, cultivation of removal, and cultivation of antidotes.
Cultivation of attainment refers to the cultivation of wholesome dharmas that have not yet arisen, causing them to arise.

Cultivation of what has arisen means cultivating the good dharmas that have already arisen so that they endure, are not forgotten, and are redoubled and expanded.ğŸ”½Cultivation of elimination means cultivating the already arisen bad and unwholesome dharmas so as to eliminate them forever.
Cultivation of antidotes means cultivating the unarisen bad and unwholesome dharmas so as to prevent their arising.
These four kinds of distinctions in cultivation correspond to the four right efforts as appropriate.
Cultivation for the sake of attainment is called cultivation of attainment, because by the power of this cultivation one attains the wholesome dharmas that have not yet been attained.
Cultivation that is just cultivation is called cultivation of practice, because by the power of this cultivation one frequently practices the wholesome dharmas that have already been attained.
Cultivation for the sake of elimination is called cultivation of elimination, because by the power of this cultivation one eliminates the unwholesome dharmas that are presently active.
Cultivation of antidotes is called cultivation of antidotes, because one cultivates the antidotes to future unwholesome dharmas in order to make them dharmas that do not arise.

Also, when the path arises, it is able to establish its own habit energy, which is called the cultivation of acquisition, because from this type, the continuity of the path increases and becomes more powerful.
Also, the cultivation of the path in the present is called the cultivation of practice, because the path itself is manifested in the present.

Also, when the path is manifested in the present, it is able to abandon its own obstacles, which is called the cultivation of removal, because it is able to eliminate the obstacles of coarseness that are to be eliminated by it.

Also, when the path has already abandoned its own obstacles, it causes them to abide in the state of non-arising in the future, which is called the cultivation of counteraction, because having attained the transmutation of the basis, it places those obstacles in the future and causes them to abide in the state of non-arising.

Also, because it is endowed with four kinds of counteraction, it is called the cultivation of counteraction, namely, the counteraction of disgust and destruction, the counteraction of elimination, the counteraction of maintenance, and the counteraction of distance.

The counteraction of disgust and destruction means seeing many faults in contaminated conditioned dharmas, that is, because one is disgusted with and destroys the five aggregates of clinging by considering them to be like illnesses, like tumors, and so forth.
The counteragent of elimination is the path of preparation and the uninterrupted path, because they are able to eliminate all the passions.
The counteragent of maintenance is the path of liberation, because it maintains the possession of the elimination.
The counteragent of distancing is the path subsequent to that, because it causes the passions previously eliminated to be distanced even further.
These four kinds of distinctions in counteragents are the meaning of the distinction in the cultivation of the previous counteragents.
